identificationModule.briefTitle: Patient-Directed Antimicrobial Duration in Acute Uncomplicated Pyelonephritis
identificationModule.officialTitle: Personalized Antibiotic Treatment in the Emergency Department: Panther Trial

descriptionModule.briefSummary: This pilot study will randomize 40 female patients with acute uncomplicated pyelonephritis to receive standard duration of therapy versus patient-directed antimicrobial duration (PDAD). The primary objectives of this pilot trial are to determine the feasibility and safety of conducting a full-scale multi-center randomized controlled trial.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: Following informed consent, patients will be randomized to receive 10 days of cephalexin or PDAD (minimum of 3 days of cephalexin followed by placebo once patient reports 24 hours of symptom resolution). Patients will be evaluated at day 1 in-person, then daily using a mobile cellphone application to assess acute uncomplicated pyelonephritis (AUP) symptoms and quality of life (QOL). Urine samples will be collected at in-person visits at day 1, 3 weeks, and 4 weeks. Study feasibility will be assessed through day 90.

interventions.name: Cephalexin
interventions.description: Cephalexin 1000 mg by mouth 3 times daily for 10 days

interventions.name: Cephalexin or placebo
interventions.description: Cephalexin 1000 mg by mouth 3 times daily for a minimum of 3 days, once participant reports symptom resolution for 24 hours they will switch to placebo for remainder of 10 days of treatment.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Feasibility of completing all clinical trial activities and follow-up
primaryOutcomes.description: Percentage of participants that complete all study activities and follow-up through 90 days

secondaryOutcomes.description: Participant does not require any additional antimicrobial treatment and they do not have a recurrence of symptoms after initial clinical improvement.
The bacterial pathogen found at trial entry is sustained to fewer than 1000 CFU/mL.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Clinical and microbiological cure rates after the end of treatment
secondaryOutcomes.description: Participant does not require any additional antimicrobial treatment and they do not have a recurrence of symptoms after initial clinical improvement AND the bacterial pathogen found at trial entry is reduced to fewer than 1000 CFU/mL.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Adverse event and side effect event rates
Additional health care visits with the chief complaint of urinary tract infection
Time to return to normal activities

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion:

* Females between 18 and 55 years of age
* Diagnosis of acute uncomplicated pyelonephritis
* Can be discharged home on oral antimicrobial treatment
* Ability to provide written informed consent in English or Spanish

Exclusion:

* Took antibiotics in the prior 48 hours
* Insulin-dependent diabetes
* End-stage liver disease
* If the patient reports a penicillin allergy, and is deemed to be high-risk using the penicillin allergy clinical decision rule (PEN-FAST)
* Serious allergy (e.g., angioedema, anaphylaxis) to the study medication or a similarly reported allergy to a cephalosporin
* Known or identified hydronephrosis, obstruction, or abscess identified by emergency department ultrasound
* Presence of a kidney stone
* Pregnancy or lactation
* Renal dysfunction (defined as creatinine clearance of less than 30 mL/min)
* Renal transplantation
* Complicated pyelonephritis (defined anatomical or functional abnormality of the urinary tract that predisposes to infection)
* Need for additional antimicrobial therapy for a coexisting infection
* Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection, with either a recent (in the past 6 months) acquired immune deficiency syndrome-defining condition or a cluster of differentiation-4 (CD-4+) T lymphocyte count \<200/mm\^3

locations.facility: University of Iowa Hospitals and Clinics
